title: Incorrect cross-platform file path resolution with include_str!
body:
Last night, I updated my local copy of Rust (stable-x86_64-windows-gnu), and updated the dependencies within my project (which mainly consists of GTK/Relm related libraries). The file structure of my project is like so:

- src
  - assets
    - style.css
  - views
    - view1.rs
    - view2.rs
    - ...
  - main.rs

The project itself is built in two ways: Locally, on my Windows 10 machine, and via CI to cross-compile it for a Raspberry Pi (running Raspbian, using target armv7-unknown-linux-gnueabihf). After updating, it seems like `include_str!`'s file path resolution logic doesn't match across the targets, seeing as my project was successfully building on both targets yesterday. To be more clear, after updating, this code:

`include_str!("assets/style.css")`

which is called from within any of the viewx.rs files, will output the following on Windows:

`couldn't read src\views\assets/style.css: The system cannot find the path specified. (os error 3)`

but will compile just fine for the Pi. Changing the path to `../assets/style.css` will allow it to compile on Windows, but will break the Pi's build, with an error of:

`error: couldn't read src/../assets/style.css: No such file or directory (os error 2)`

I'm not sure what `include_str!` is looking for in terms of path now, as previously 'assets/style.css' correctly pointed to the file on both targets (and by previously I mean likely Rust 1.29 - I also switched from nightly to stable but the error persists on both). [The docs for `include_str!`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/macro.include_str.html) say that the path should be relative to the 'current file'. It seems that on Windows, the 'current file' is the file that's calling `include_str!` (i.e. view1.rs), whereas on the Pi/Linux, it's main.rs itself.
